image.altText: Joe Biden sits at his Oval Office desk and speaks.

title.children: 'Facing inflection point': Biden gives rare prime-time address in bid for Ukraine, Israel funds

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It is now just after 6am in Israel. Here's what you might have missed: The United States has issued a worldwide travel warning amid raised terror fears US President Joe Biden has wrapped up his visit to Israel with a warning against being 'consumed' by rage European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has said the risk of regional spillover from the Israel-Hamas war is "real" European Council President Charles Michel says Egypt needs support to handle those fleeing Gaza Biden gave a national address in which he is seeking $100 billion in funding for several causes including for Israel to defend itself against terror attacks and for humanitarian aid for Gaza Pro-Palestinian protesters have blocked the entry to the joint Australian-US Defence facility No 'immediate plans' for more flights for Australians from Israel
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here are the latest developments from Israel and Gaza

children.content: It is now just after 6am in Israel. Here's what you might have missed:
The United States has issued a
worldwide travel warning amid raised terror fears
US President Joe Biden has wrapped up his visit to Israel with a
warning
against being 'consumed' by rage
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has said the risk of
regional spillover from the Israel-Hamas war is "real"
European Council President Charles Michel says
Egypt needs support to handle those fleeing Gaza
Biden gave a national address in which he is seeking
$100 billion in funding for several causes including for Israel to defend itself against terror attacks and for humanitarian aid for Gaza
Pro-Palestinian protesters have
blocked the entry to the joint Australian-US Defence facility
No 'immediate plans' for more
flights for Australians from Israel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged Australians to "donate responsibly". "The best way to assist people in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories is to donate money to a reputable organisation with an established presence in the area," the department wrote on social media. "We recommend donating through members of the Australian Council for International Development."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: DFAT issues reminder to Australians wanting to donate

children.content: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has urged Australians to "donate responsibly".

"The best way to assist people in Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories is to donate money to a reputable organisation with an established presence in the area," the department wrote on social media.
"We recommend donating through members of the Australian Council for International Development."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another flight from Tel Aviv carrying Australians has landed in Dubai overnight, according to Foreign Minister Penny Wong. "We are planning an assisted departure flight from Dubai to Perth tonight," she wrote on social media. She added that due to "diminishing demand for dedicated assisted-departure flights", there were no "immediate plans" for more flights from Tel Aviv. "We continue to work with partners to assist the departure of Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories," she said. "Commercial flights departing Tel Aviv remain available."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No 'immediate plans' for more flights for Australians from Israel

children.content: Another flight from Tel Aviv carrying Australians has landed in Dubai overnight, according to Foreign Minister Penny Wong.
"We are planning an assisted departure flight from Dubai to Perth tonight," she wrote on social media.
She added that due to "diminishing demand for dedicated assisted-departure flights", there were no "immediate plans" for more flights from Tel Aviv.
"We continue to work with partners to assist the departure of Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories," she said.
"Commercial flights departing Tel Aviv remain available."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas recently announced its chairman Richard Goyder had bowed to shareholder pressure and agreed to leave the troubled airline's board next year, joined by two of his fellow directors — Maxine Brenner and chairwoman of the remuneration committee, Jacqueline Hey. They have agreed to leave at Qantas' interim result in February, while Mr Goyder will step down ahead of the 2024 annual general meeting — but in Goyder's case some say that is not soon enough. You can learn more about that here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zmopL2u9Nxw But it seems investors still want more board rejuvenation at Qantas. On Wednesday Ms Brenner faced a 17 per cent protest vote against her re-election at Telstra, after proxy firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended against her because of her concurrent board role at the airline. But what for Todd Sampson? The Qantas board's in-house marketing and public relations expert may be the next target of big investors. Proxy adviser Ownership Matter has recommended Mr Sampson be forced to exit the company at the national carrier's upcoming annual general meeting. While another adviser to institutional investors, ISS, "notes" ongoing concerns about accountability, as well as Mr Sampson's role on the remuneration committee. It will be interesting to see how investors react when the airline holds its annual general meeting at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre on November 3.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Can Qantas directors like Todd Sampson survive the November 3 AGM?

children.content: Qantas recently announced its chairman Richard Goyder had bowed to shareholder pressure and agreed to leave the troubled airline's board next year, joined by two of his fellow directors — Maxine Brenner and chairwoman of the remuneration committee, Jacqueline Hey.
They have agreed to leave at Qantas' interim result in February, while Mr Goyder will step down ahead of the 2024 annual general meeting — but in Goyder's case some say that is not soon enough.
You can learn more about that here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zmopL2u9Nxw

But it seems investors still want more board rejuvenation at Qantas. On Wednesday Ms Brenner faced a 17 per cent protest vote against her re-election at Telstra, after proxy firm Institutional Shareholder Services recommended against her because of her concurrent board role at the airline.
But what for Todd Sampson? The Qantas board's in-house marketing and public relations expert may be the next target of big investors.
Todd Sampson may come under pressure at the AGM
(ABC News)
Proxy adviser Ownership Matter has recommended Mr Sampson be forced to exit the company at the national carrier's upcoming annual general meeting.
While another adviser to institutional investors, ISS, "notes" ongoing concerns about accountability, as well as Mr Sampson's role on the remuneration committee.
It will be interesting to see how investors react when the airline holds its annual general meeting at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre on November 3.
